reasoning:
First things first: NFLX lies outside my circle of competence. I don’t pretend to understand the intricacies of streaming algorithms, content licensing and subscriber churn, so right off the bat I’m at a disadvantage. In my 60 years I’ve stuck to businesses I deeply understand – utilities, consumer staples, insurance and the like. 

The moat here is questionable. Yes, Netflix has strong brand recognition and scale, but its inconsistent ROE (only 1 of 10 years above 15%), spotty earnings growth and limited pricing power suggest any advantage is neither wide nor enduring. A real economic moat means you can raise prices without losing customers; the data show Netflix has yet to prove that consistently. 

Management has chosen to dilute shareholders through stock issuance rather than returning cash via dividends or buybacks. That’s not how I like owners to think. Capital allocation should favor high returns for existing shareholders, not just fueling endless content spending. 

Financially, Netflix looks shaky. Weak ROE of 3.6%, negative owner-earnings and an inconsistent earnings pattern are flags. A solid business should deliver steady, predictable cash flows – Netflix does not. 

Valuation is another deal-killer. The three-stage DCF spits out a negative intrinsic value, meaning you’d be paying for a business that generates negative free cash flow. A margin of safety of -108% is as wide a moat as you’ll find – here in reverse. 

Long term, streaming remains competitive and capital hungry. New entrants and legacy studios with deep pockets will keep pushing costs and churn higher. I prefer businesses that earn profits consistently decade after decade with minimal need for reinvestment. 

Compare this to Coca-Cola, Apple or BNSF – companies with durable moats, predictable cash flows and simple economics. When in doubt, the answer is no. I see no reason to make an exception here. Bearish.

fundamental_analysis.details: Weak ROE of 3.6%; Conservative debt levels; Strong operating margins; Current ratio data not available

consistency_analysis.details: Inconsistent earnings growth pattern; Total earnings growth of 175.3% over past 10 periods

moat_analysis.details: Inconsistent ROE: only 1/10 periods >15%; Decent operating margins (avg: 46.6%) suggest some competitive advantage

book_value_analysis.details: Consistent book value per share growth (Buffett's favorite metric)

management_analysis.details: Recent common stock issuance (potential dilution); No or minimal dividends paid

details: Using three-stage DCF: Stage 1 (3.6%, 5y), Stage 2 (1.8%, 5y), Terminal (2.5%)
